conclusion: The basketball is dropped from rest at a height H above the ground.
It undergoes an inelastic collision with the ground and rebounds to a maximum height h above the ground.
The magnitude of the air resistance experienced by the basketball is λ times the magnitude of the gravitational force acting on the basketball.
The total kinetic energy of the basketball before the collision is KE_initial = 1/2 mv^2.
The total kinetic energy of the basketball after the collision is KE_final = 1/2 mv'_final^2.
According to the conservation of energy, KE_initial = KE_final.
The initial velocity of the basketball is v = sqrt(2gH).
The final velocity of the basketball after the collision is v'_final = sqrt(2g(h + λh)).
The post-collision velocity is v'_final = sqrt(2g(h + λh)).
The ratio of the post-collision velocity to the pre-collision velocity is v'_final/v = sqrt(2g(h + λh))/sqrt(2gH).
Simplifying the ratio, we get v'_final/v = sqrt(2g(h + λh))/sqrt(2gH) = sqrt(2g(h + λh))/H.
The ratio of the post-collision velocity to the pre-collision velocity of the basketball during its collision with the ground is sqrt(2g(h + λh))/H.
